data.message: although he is not by any mean a relative or close to me, I felt sad and really sorry for the world to lose such a genius man like him.
Believe it or not, I felt that from the moment of stepping down as CEO, i feel so sad  ... The Inventor of GUI has passed away :'(
I'm sorry, but Steve Jobs did not invent the GUI, it was already invented at Xerox, he merely bought it from them.

Xerox !! you can said that it is xerox if you recognize that GUI is only using a mouse to control commands on screen, but the core (Explorer, Controls, splitting from terminals and consoles into fully graphics) is for sure for Apple ...
And thats why Microsoft rushed to turn its MS-DOS into GUI based system ... Windows :)
Xerox didn't make apps for it, but they had the basic idea, and that's the tricky part.
besides, Steve Jobs isn't even a programmer, how could he possibly invent a program when he's not a programmer?

Yeah you right, steve is not a programmer and didnt know any thing about that, but he is a prototyper ... a very good visionary mind, shifted computing experience from bulky enterprise architecture into micro-architecture that can be used on our homes ...
uh, as far as I know, Steve Wozniak was the first to build the PC as we know it, Jobs took care of marketing, so it was Wozniak's work, not Jobs'
and think of it again , this xerox sparc machine is a device that embedded a controller system ...
Does that mean he "Invented" the GUI?
Hah! ... No, Wozniak is the programming guy, but under the vision of steve
ok ... to be more clear: Steve invented the full based GUI system, not the GUI of puppet embedded controllers.
Read more about the Xerox Alto on Wikipedia, it had a lot of the features of a modern PC.
I Think MS DOS looks sexier .... huh !  http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/10/Alto_Neptune_Filemanager.gif/450px-Alto_Neptune_Filemanager.gif

And the more pc-like Xerox Star was not originally meant to be a stand-alone computer, but to be part of an integrated Xerox "personal office system" that also connected to other workstations and network services via Ethernet
Simply a controller for Mainframe Workstations ... Which cannot do all things PC did by the way (At that Era)
